definition.name: NXdetector

symbols.doc: These symbols will be used below to coordinate datasets with the same shape.

symbol.name: np
symbol.doc: number of scan points (only present in scanning measurements)

symbol.name: i
symbol.doc: number of detector pixels in the first (X, slowest) direction

symbol.name: j
symbol.doc: number of detector pixels in the second (Y, faster) direction

symbol.name: k
symbol.doc: number of detector pixels in the third (Z, if necessary, fastest) direction

symbol.name: tof
symbol.doc: number of bins in the time-of-flight histogram

definition.doc: A detector, detector bank, or multidetector.

field.name: time_of_flight
field.doc: Total time of flight

field.name: raw_time_of_flight
field.doc: In DAQ clock pulses

field.name: detector_number
field.doc: Identifier for detector (pixels) Can be multidimensional, if needed

field.name: data
field.doc: Data values from the detector.

attribute.name: check_sum
attribute.doc: Integral of data as check of data integrity

field.name: data_error
field.doc: The best estimate of the uncertainty in the data value. Where possible, this should be the standard deviation, which has the same units as the data.

field.name: x_pixel_offset
field.doc: Offset from the detector center in x-direction. Can be multidimensional when needed.

field.name: y_pixel_offset
field.doc: Offset from the detector center in the y-direction. Can be multidimensional when different values are required for each pixel.

field.name: z_pixel_offset
field.doc: Offset from the detector center in the z-direction. Can be multidimensional when different values are required for each pixel.

field.name: distance
field.doc: This is the distance to the previous component in the instrument; most often the sample. The usage depends on the nature of the detector: Most often it is the distance of the detector assembly. But there are irregular detectors. In this case the distance must be specified for each detector pixel.

field.name: polar_angle
field.doc: This is the polar angle of the detector towards the previous component in the instrument; most often the sample. The usage depends on the nature of the detector. Most often it is the polar_angle of the detector assembly. But there are irregular detectors. In this case, the polar_angle must be specified for each detector pixel.

field.name: azimuthal_angle
field.doc: This is the azimuthal angle angle of the detector towards the previous component in the instrument; most often the sample. The usage depends on the nature of the detector. Most often it is the azimuthal_angle of the detector assembly. But there are irregular detectors. In this case, the azimuthal_angle must be specified for each detector pixel.

field.name: description
field.doc: name/manufacturer/model/etc. information

field.name: serial_number
field.doc: Serial number for the detector

field.name: local_name
field.doc: Local name for the detector

field.name: solid_angle
field.doc: Solid angle subtended by the detector at the sample

field.name: x_pixel_size
field.doc: Size of each detector pixel. If it is scalar all pixels are the same size.

field.name: y_pixel_size
field.doc: Size of each detector pixel. If it is scalar all pixels are the same size

field.name: dead_time
field.doc: Detector dead time

field.name: gas_pressure
field.doc: Detector gas pressure

field.name: detection_gas_path
field.doc: maximum drift space dimension

field.name: crate
field.doc: Crate number of detector

field.name: slot
field.doc: Slot number of detector

field.name: input
field.doc: Input number of detector

field.name: type
field.doc: Description of type such as He3 gas cylinder, He3 PSD, scintillator, fission chamber, proportion counter, ion chamber, ccd, pixel, image plate, CMOS, ...

group.name: efficiency
group.doc: Spectral efficiency of detector with respect to e.g. wavelength

field.name: efficiency
field.doc: efficiency of the detector

field.name: wavelength
field.doc:
This field can be two things:
#. For a pixel detector it provides the nominal wavelength for which the detector has been calibrated.
#. For other detectors this field has to be seen together with the efficiency field above. For some detectors, the efficiency is wavelength dependent. Thus this field provides the wavelength axis for the efficiency field. In this use case, the efficiency and wavelength arrays must have the same dimensionality.

field.name: start_time
field.doc: start time for each frame, with the ``start`` attribute as absolute reference

field.name: stop_time
field.doc: stop time for each frame, with the ``start`` attribute as absolute reference

field.name: real_time
field.doc: real-time of the exposure (use this if exposure time varies for each array element, otherwise use ``count_time`` field)

field.name: calibration_date
field.doc: date of last calibration (geometry and/or efficiency) measurements

group.name: calibration_method
group.doc: summary of conversion of array data to pixels (e.g. polynomial approximations) and location of details of the calibrations

field.name: layout
field.doc: How the detector is represented

field.name: count_time
field.doc: Elapsed actual counting time

group.doc: Use this group to provide other data related to this NXdetector group.

field.name: sequence_number
field.doc: In order to properly sort the order of the images taken in (for example) a tomography experiment, a sequence number is stored with each image.

field.name: beam_center_x
field.doc: This is the x position where the direct beam would hit the detector. This is a length and can be outside of the actual detector. The length can be in physical units or pixels as documented by the units attribute.

field.name: beam_center_y
field.doc: This is the y position where the direct beam would hit the detector. This is a length and can be outside of the actual detector. The length can be in physical units or pixels as documented by the units attribute.

field.name: frame_start_number
field.doc: This is the start number of the first frame of a scan. In PX one often scans a couple of frames on a give sample, then does something else, then returns to the same sample and scans some more frames. Each time with a new data file. This number helps concatenating such measurements.

field.name: diameter
field.doc: The diameter of a cylindrical detector

field.name: acquisition_mode
field.doc: The acquisition mode of the detector.

field.name: angular_calibration_applied
field.doc: True when the angular calibration has been applied in the electronics, false otherwise.

field.name: angular_calibration
field.doc: Angular calibration data.

field.name: flatfield_applied
field.doc: True when the flat field correction has been applied in the electronics, false otherwise.

field.name: flatfield
field.doc: Flat field correction data.

field.name: flatfield_error
field.doc: Errors of the flat field correction data.

field.name: pixel_mask_applied
field.doc: True when the pixel mask correction has been applied in the electronics, false otherwise.

field.name: pixel_mask
field.doc:
The 32-bit pixel mask for the detector. Contains a bit field for each pixel to signal dead, blind or high or otherwise unwanted or undesirable pixels. They have the following meaning:
.. can't make a table here, a bullet list will have to do for now
* bit 0: gap (pixel with no sensor) * bit 1: dead * bit 2: under responding * bit 3: over responding * bit 4: noisy * bit 5: -undefined- * bit 6: pixel is part of a cluster of problematic pixels (bit set in addition to others) * bit 7: -undefined- * bit 8: user defined mask (e.g. around beamstop) * bits 9-30: -undefined- * bit 31: virtual pixel (corner pixel with interpolated value)
The normal data analysis software would not take pixels into account when a bit in (mask & 0x00FF) is set. Tag bit in the upper two bytes would indicate special pixel properties that normally would not be a sole reason to reject the intensity value (unless lower bits are also set).

field.name: countrate_correction__applied
field.doc: True when a count-rate correction has already been applied in the electronics, false otherwise.

field.name: bit_depth_readout
field.doc: How many bits the electronics reads per pixel. With CCD's and single photon counting detectors, this must not align with traditional integer sizes. This can be 4, 8, 12, 14, 16, ...

field.name: detector_readout_time
field.doc: Time it takes to read the detector (typically milliseconds). This is important to know for time resolved experiments.

field.name: trigger_delay_time
field.doc: Time it takes to start exposure after a trigger signal has been received. This is the reaction time of the detector firmware after receiving the trigger signal to when the detector starts to acquire the exposure, including any user set delay.. This is important to know for time resolved experiments.

field.name: trigger_delay_time_set
field.doc: User-specified trigger delay.

field.name: trigger_internal_delay_time
field.doc: Time it takes to start exposure after a trigger signal has been received. This is the reaction time of the detector hardware after receiving the trigger signal to when the detector starts to acquire the exposure. It forms the lower boundary of the trigger_delay_time when the user does not request an additional delay.

field.name: trigger_dead_time
field.doc: Time during which no new trigger signal can be accepted. Typically this is the trigger_delay_time + exposure_time + readout_time. This is important to know for time resolved experiments.

field.name: frame_time
field.doc: This is time for each frame. This is exposure_time + readout time.

field.name: gain_setting
field.doc: The gain setting of the detector. This influences background etc.

field.name: saturation_value
field.doc: The value at which the detector goes into saturation. Especially common to CCD detectors, the data is known to be invalid above this value.

field.name: number_of_cycles
field.doc: CCD images are sometimes constructed by summing together multiple short exposures in the electronics. This reduces background etc. This is the number of short exposures used to sum images for an image.

field.name: sensor_material
field.doc: At times, radiation is not directly sensed by the detector. Rather, the detector might sense the output from some converter like a scintillator. This is the name of this converter material.

field.name: sensor_thickness
field.doc: At times, radiation is not directly sensed by the detector. Rather, the detector might sense the output from some converter like a scintillator. This is the thickness of this converter material.

field.name: threshold_energy
field.doc: Single photon counter detectors can be adjusted for a certain energy range in which they work optimally. This is the energy setting for this.

group.doc:
For use in special cases where the data in NXdetector is represented in several parts, each with a separate geometry.
Use one or more instances of the NXdetector_module group to declare regions of interest or some other subdivision of a detector.
Shape description of each pixel. Use only if all pixels in the detector are of uniform shape.
Shape description of each pixel. Use only if all pixels in the detector are of uniform shape and require being described by cylinders.
Shape description of the whole detector. Use only if pixels in the detector are not of uniform shape.
Shape description of the whole detector. Use only if pixels in the detector are not of uniform shape and require being described by cylinders.
